newsitem.title: UK: BADMINTON-SUSANTI WORLD TITLE HOPES SHATTERED.
newsitem.headline: BADMINTON-SUSANTI WORLD TITLE HOPES SHATTERED.

text.p: Susi Susanti's hopes of a second world badminton title were shattered again on Friday.
The stylish Indonesian was swept aside in the quarter-finals 11-5 11-2 by 19-year-old Gong Zhichao of China.
Susanti, a former Olympic, world and all-England champion, has been hinting at retirement for some time now. She is married to long-time fiance Allan Budi Kusuma.

But despite Friday's defeat she indicated she would be playing on. "I would like to play for maybe one more year," she told reporters. "I'd also like to help train the youngsters who are coming through.
"I'd like to try for other tournaments because I still have the motivation to play and to win," she added.
Whether she can handle the emerging talent, much of it Chinese, remains to be seen.
China dominated last week's Sudiman Cup team event and they have made their presence felt agian, providing six of the eight women's quarter-finalists.
While Gong dealt with Susanti, Wang Chen put paid to Mia Audina, the third seed, 11-6 11-4 in another big blow for the Indonesians.
With four Chinese fighting out the other two quarter-finals it meant that all the women's semifinalists on Saturday will be from China.
Indonesian hopes now rest with men's defending champion Heryanto Arbi, who fought back to beat Denmark's Thomas Stuer-Lauridesn 10-15 15-6 15-1.
In Saturday's semifinals he plays Denmark's Peter Rasmussen, a good 15-2 18-17 winner over South Korea's Park Sung-woo.
The other semifinal will be between Olympic champion Poul-Erik Hoyer-Larsen and former world junior champion Sun Jun of China.
Hoyer-Larsen wobbled for a while against former world champion Joko Suprianto of Indonesia before emerging a 10-15 15-9 15-5 winner.
Greater patience and stamina paid off for Hoyer-Larsen, who reported that "in the end it was like hooking a fish and bringing it in".
